summary: This is a cover letter from Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys to Judge Alison J. Nathan, submitting under seal a renewed motion for bail and requesting narrowly tailored redactions based on privacy concerns and the inclusion of confidential discovery materials.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell

connections.description: Mark S. Cohen is an attorney representing Ghislaine Maxwell in her criminal case, as indicated by the phrase 'On behalf of our client, Ghislaine Maxwell'.
Christian R. Everdell is an attorney representing Ghislaine Maxwell in her criminal case, as indicated by the phrase 'On behalf of our client, Ghislaine Maxwell'.
Both are attorneys at Cohen & Gresser LLP and are co-signatories on the legal submission for their client Ghislaine Maxwell.
Judge Nathan is the presiding judge over the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Submission of Renewed Bail Motion
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys submit under seal a renewed motion for bail and a redacted public version, citing privacy and confidential discovery materials.

events.title: Defense Letter on Privacy Concerns
events.description: The defense submitted a letter (Dkt. 86) articulating privacy concerns, referenced as a basis for proposed redactions in the bail motion.

events.title: Defense Follow-up Letter
events.description: The defense submitted another letter (Dkt. 87) further articulating concerns, referenced as a basis for proposed redactions in the bail motion.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York, 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team is submitting a renewed motion for bail under seal, indicating ongoing pre-trial proceedings in her criminal case.

The defense is requesting narrowly tailored redactions for a public version of the motion, citing privacy concerns and the inclusion of confidential discovery materials governed by a protective order.
The document references prior defense submissions (Dkt. 86, 87) from late November 2020 regarding privacy, showing a sequence of legal arguments related to sealing information.
The case is United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, 20 Cr. 330 (MN), presided over by Judge Alison J. Nathan in the Southern District of New York.
